Animations#

Spacecraft motion#

class src.blender.Animation.SpacecraftMotion.SpacecraftMotion#

Bases: object

Time scale in seconds Space scale in kilometers FPS of simulation

add_cycles_modifier(fcurve)#

Add a ‘CYCLES’ modifier to the given fcurve.

Parameters:

fcurve (bpy.types.FCurve) – The fcurve to add the modifier to.

apply_axis_angle_rotation_to_object(obj, axis, period_frames, phase=0.0)#

Apply axis-angle rotation to the object.

Parameters:

  • obj (bpy.types.Object) – The object to apply rotation to.

  • axis (tuple) – The axis of rotation as a tuple (x, y, z).

  • period_frames (int) – The number of frames for one complete rotation.

  • phase (float) – The initial phase angle in degrees (default: 0).

apply_linear_movement(obj, start, end, frame_start, frame_end)#

Apply linear movement animation to an object in Blender.

Parameters:

  • obj (bpy.types.Object) – The object to animate.

  • start (tuple or list of three floats (x, y, z)) – The starting location of the object.

  • end (tuple or list of three floats (x, y, z)) – The ending location of the object.

  • frame_start (int) – The starting frame for the animation.

  • frame_end (int) – The ending frame for the animation.

constraint_trackto(track_axis, up_axis, object, target)#

Add a “Track To” constraint to the specified object, making it track a target.

Parameters:

  • track_axis (str) – The axis along which the object should track the target (e.g., ‘TRACK_X’, ‘TRACK_NEGATIVE_Y’, etc.).

  • up_axis (str) – The axis that should be aligned with the target’s up direction (e.g., ‘UP_X’, ‘UP_Y’, etc.).

  • object (bpy.types.Object) – The object to which the constraint will be added.

  • target (bpy.types.Object) – The target object that the ‘object’ should track.

create_camera(name, location=(0, 0, 0), rotation=(0, 0, 0))#

Function which creates a camera with given name, location, and rotation. It also links the camera to the seen and sets it as active. NOTE: Camera setting have to be specified with the set_camera_optics_as_fov() function

Parameters:

  • name (str) – Defines the name of the camera

  • location (float[]) – Array with the initial cooridinates of the camera in euler angles

  • rotation (float[]) – Array with initialy rotation of the camera

Returns:

returns the created camera object

Return type:

bpy.data.objects

create_points_spacecraft(name, parent=None)#

Create a spacecraft point with an optional parent.

Parameters:

  • name (str) – The name of the spacecraft object.

  • parent (bpy.types.Object) – The parent object to link to (default: None).

Returns:

The created spacecraft object.

Return type:

bpy.types.Object

create_spacecraft_hierarchy(spacecraft_hierarchy)#

Reads the given dictionary and creates all the spacecraft points with create_points_spacecraft(). It also links the created object with the defined parent object.

Parameters:

spacecraft_hierarchy (dict) – Dictionary containing all spacecraft points and parents

Returns:

The dictionary of created spacecraft objects

Return type:

dict

set_camera_optics_as_fov(camera_object, camera_specs)#

Sets the camera optics with the units as field of view.

Parameters:

  • angle (float) – The angle of the the field of view (default = 0.31765)

  • clip_start (float) – Closest rendering with this camera (default = 0.1)

  • clip_end (float) – Farthest rendering with this camera (default = 100000)

set_keyframe_interpolation(fcurve, interpolation)#

Set the interpolation mode for each keyframe point in the given fcurve.

Parameters:

  • fcurve (bpy.types.FCurve) – The fcurve to set the keyframe interpolation for.

  • interpolation (str) – The interpolation mode to set (‘CONSTANT’, ‘LINEAR’, ‘BEZIER’, etc.).

setup_flyby(fly_by_params, fps)#

Set up spacecraft flyby based on the provided flyby parameters.

Parameters:

fly_by_params (dict): A dictionary containing flyby parameters. fps (int): Frames per second for animation.

This function sets up the flyby for the spacecraft objects based on the provided parameters. It calculates start and end position and frame.

Example of rotation_params dictionary:

fly_by_params = {
    "speed": 80,
    "t_start": -1220,
    "t_end": -1200,
    "closest_fly_by": [0, 400, 0],
    "fly_by_azimuth_degrees": 0

}
Note:

The fly by parameters must be defined and set up correctly before calling this function.

setup_rotations(rotation_params, spacecraft_objects, fps)#

Set up spacecraft rotations based on the provided rotation parameters.

Parameters:

rotation_params (dict): A dictionary containing rotation parameters. spacecraft_objects (dict): A dictionary containing spacecraft objects. fps (int): Frames per second for animation.

This function sets up the rotations for the spacecraft objects based on the provided rotation parameters. It applies the axis-angle rotation to various objects to create the desired animation.

Example of rotation_params dictionary:
rotation_params = {

“B2_main_rotation”: {“period”: 4}, “B2_precession”: {“period”: 100, “angle_deg”: -15}, “B2_nutation”: {“period”: 20, “angle_deg”: 5},

}

Example of spacecraft_objects dictionary:

spacecraft_objects = {
    "OPIC_main_pointing": <bpy.types.Object>,
    "OPIC_B2_precessing_rotation": <bpy.types.Object>,
    "NutatingAxis": <bpy.types.Object>,
    "PrecessingMisalignment": <bpy.types.Object>,
    "NutationMisalignment": <bpy.types.Object>,
    "B2Propagator": <bpy.types.Object>,
    "OPICOrigin": <bpy.types.Object>,
    "start_point": <bpy.types.Object>,
    "end_point": <bpy.types.Object>,
    "closest_point": <bpy.types.Object>,
    "OPIC": <bpy.types.Object>,

}
Note:

The rotation parameters and spacecraft objects must be defined and set up correctly before calling this function.
